intro: Aphananthe aspera var. pubescens, commonly known as the hairy mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic shrub native to Australia. It belongs to the family Loranthaceae and is characterized by its dense, evergreen foliage and small, clustered white flowers. The plant has a rough, hairy texture on its stems and leaves, which gives it its specific epithet "pubescens." It typically grows on the branches of eucalyptus and other host trees, deriving some of its nutrients from the host. The fruit is a small, fleshy berry that contains several seeds, aiding in its dispersal by birds.
